headline.main: For Some, Diet Pills Are Worth the Risk

docs.abstract: Elsa A Solender letter on Sept 17 editorial on recall of diet drugs fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Diet Pill Excesses'' (editorial, Sept. 17): Is there no room in your editorial to reflect the disappointment of many who struggle with the disease of obesity at the loss of what seemed to be a promising treatment? The drugs fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine brought hope and relief not only to ''millions who want to shed 5 or 10 pounds'' but also to others whose loss of 20 or 30 pounds represented a significant health benefit.

headline.main: Dispiriting Dilemma For Dieters in U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: Monday's recall of two popular diet drugs has presented a dilemma that involves a choice between health risks and the hope of losing weight for Americans fighting obesity and those trying to respond to the dictates of a weight-obsessed culture.

headline.main: Recall of Drugs Leaves Many Dieters Hopeless

docs.abstract: Dieters react with despair and even sparks of defiance to recall of weight-loss drugs Redux (dexfenfluramine) and Pondimin (fenfluramine), despite heart risks now linked to drugs; many view drug combination fen-phen as miracle pill; many of weight-loss clinics that prescribe drugs seem to have already gone out of business in face of negative publicity; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: They know. They know that the drugs would not have been recalled lightly. But still, among the millions of American dieters who had seen Redux and the fen-phen combination as the weight-loss magic they crave, there were voices today expressing a loss of hope, and even sparks of defiance. ''If they sell them in Canada, I'll drive up there and come back with a carload of them,'' said Marlena Bendt, a 65-year-old woman in Hoffman Estates, Ill., who has struggled with her weight all her life and recently lost 70 pounds on fen-phen. ''There are people who can't live without those drugs. For me, fen-phen is an alternative to dying.''

headline.main: 2 Top Diet Drugs Are Recalled Amid Reports of Heart Defects

docs.abstract: Makers of popular diet drugs, Fenfluramine (Pondimin) and Dexfenfluramine (Redux), will withdraw them from market at request of Food and Drug Administration, which says new information indicates they may cause heart valve damage in as many as 30 percent of people who take them; Commissioner Michael A Friedman says agency is taking issue seriously, even though evidence that drugs caused heart defects and other health problems is not ironclad (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The makers of two popular diet drugs announced yesterday that they were withdrawing them from the market at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, which said new information indicates that the drugs may cause heart valve damage in as many as 30 percent of people who take them. The drugs are fenfluramine, or Pondimin, and dexfenfluramine, or Redux, and are often used in combination with phentermine, an amphetamine-like drug, as part of the combination known as fen-phen.

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health article discusses factors common among formerly obese people who have succeeded in losing and keeping off significant weight; notes most modified both eating and exercise habits and developed ways to deal with cravings and stress that enabled them to stick to diets; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PROFESSIONAL beliefs about the possibility of long-term weight loss by those who have a lot to lose have not changed much since 1958, when the renowned obesity specialist Dr. Albert J. Stunkard of the University of Pennsylvania said: ''Most obese persons will not stay in treatment. Of those who stay in treatment, most will not lose weight, and of those who do lose weight, most will regain it.''
